awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  AI-assisted Job Search in the Aftermath of the Covid-19 Crisis
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a technology that will help customer-facing businesses hire from a pool of candidates that have no prior experience in the sector.  The proposed technology may be used by hiring managers in mid- to large-scale employers of entry-level service workers. It is anticipated that the beachhead market will be retail. The key insights from preliminary customer discovery were that in large stores with >10k employees, the turnover in entry level positions is very high (e.g., 76% in retail in 2019) and each entry-level vacancy attracts a high volume of applications (e.g., up to 1,000 applications per position). Applicants for these vacancies are often indistinguishable given limited technical skills and previous experience.  Therefore, current screening process for entry-level positions relies heavily on arbitrary filtering heuristics, individual judgement, and interviews, and, as a result, can be particularly prone to discrimination. In addition, employers aim to hire candidates with particular soft skills (e.g., conscientiousness, attention to detail, intrinsic motivation, communication), but find it difficult to objectively measure them. In addition, the cost of replacing a worker who leaves, excluding lost productivity, is high (typically 1.5 to 2.5 times the worker’s annual salary).  By focusing on psychometric and simulated tasks, the proposed technology: a) reduces the risk of systemic discrimination while hiring; b) allows employers to cheaply, quickly and fairly identify best-suited candidates from a pool of indistinguishable candidates; c) have the ability to match workers to best-suited occupations by documenting the transferability of skills across occupations and sectors. The hypothesis is that the technology may reduce screening and hiring costs by more than 60% per head hired, in addition to finding employees that attrit at a lower rate.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of machine learning classification algorithms that use psychometric profiles and performance on simulated tasks to identify best-suited candidates for entry-level customer facing occupations. These tasks have been designed in partnership with employers in each industry to mirror actual work. To select the optimal algorithm for each task, the proposed technology uses a cost function that takes into account the losses to the employer from wrongfully rejecting qualified individuals as well as from interviewing unqualified applicants. Additionally, the proposed technology uses labor market parameters in balancing false positive and false negative predictions in selecting and calibrating the algorithms, which pushes even the frontier in this space, and is beyond the capabilities of any practical solutions in the market today.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our product aims at providing employers with a way to i) determine predicted fit and ii) hire a workforce suited for specific tasks will make it easier to retain new employees. Our initial goal behind this product was to create a machine-learning algorithm to screen and rank good-fit candidates from a large employee pool, focusing on the healthcare industry, specifically of non-clinical entry-level staff in medium to large hospitals. The necessity for such an algorithm was heightened by the Covid-19 pandemic; turnover continued to remain high, and recently, the number of unfilled vacancies in the frontline healthcare sector has also risen (BLS, 2022), which demonstrated a large gap between the demand and supply of labor.

 

Our work carried out using this award involved training and testing an AI-assisted algorithm leveraging data on job seeker characteristics, as well as the requirements of posted vacancies in the healthcare industry across and geographies made available by the rise of online job search engines. Our main activities are listed below: 

 

  1. Training our algorithm: We created two scores: “AI score” and “preference score”. To create the former, we fielded a survey of 360 respondents recruited via Monster.com and Craigslist, which consists of 181 questions involving 12 modules of curated psychometric (“Big Five,” self-esteem, motivation, ability to read emotions, and fluid intelligence, among others) and memory tests, as well as job market preferences and past employment history. The “preference score” is calculated for each job and user, following a rules-based algorithm that first ranks each of the nine sectors based on a user's preferences and then ranks jobs within those sectors based on job-specific criteria, like distance from a user's home, salary, and number of hours.
  2. Testing our algorithm: We recruited 1000 participants seeking jobs in entry-level positions to take part in a Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT). The prohibitive cost of securing job vacancy data for the entire United States across the entire period of analysis led us to target seven major metropolitan areas: Atlanta, GA; Chicago, IL; Cleveland, OH; Las Vegas, NV; Phoenix-Tucson, AZ; Sacramento-San Francisco-Oakland-San Jose, CA; Seattle, WA.

Our RCT consisted of three treatment arms

  • Control Group
  • T1 - Reduced search cost (preference score)
  • T2 - Improved information (AI score)
  • T3 - Reduced search cost and improved information (AI and preference scores)

By comparing these three arms with the control group, we aimed to estimate the causal impacts of access to algorithmic candidate-vacancy match technology on the quality and durability of match and search behaviors. Furthermore, we compare these results across gender and race/ethnicity to determine whether our intervention can reduce the strategy used by some screening algorithms of using job history as part of the hiring process. 

  1. Creating a job-search platform:  We created our own platform (www.HelpingJobSeekerss.org), inspired by other job search aggregators focusing on entry-level jobs, and, in preparation for our experiment, we conducted usability testing of the website to solicit and implement feedback to improve the functionality and design of the platform. Job vacancies are provided by Monster.com and Aspen Tech Labs over the life of the experiment are updated daily.

Main results: 

 

We present below very preliminary, but quite encouraging results for a number of outcomes in the follow-up surveys for the sample interested in the healthcare industry: 

 

  • Our target population is job seekers who may not necessarily be unemployed. In fact, about 45% of people in the sample are employed either part-time or full-time at baseline. In the month before the baseline survey, they spent about 26-27 hours per month searching for jobs. They tend to send out 22-23 applications, are invited to 2 interviews, and receive one job offer. 
  • The joint treatment (AI + Preference score) helps job seekers that may not have considered healthcare to potentially switch to that industry. This arm also opens the possibility to partner with the healthcare industry (mid-size hospitals) to help them improve their job descriptions to those preferred by the qualified (previously screened) applicants on the platform. 
  • We have found so far that participants respondents randomized to the third arm (both the preference and the AI scores) experience a 13.97 percentage point decrease in their average number of hours searching for jobs. 

Taken together, these sort of results suggest that all treatments allow participants to focus their search. The preference score reduces the need for participants to click on every job they may be interested in and focus on those that fit their preferences more closely, and the AI score may allow seekers to ignore certain occupations, which could help explain the fall in search hours.
